elements.content: In this study, copper(I) iodides and N,N′-bis(pyridylcarbonyl)-4,4′-diaminodiphenyl ether (papo) reacted to give new metal−organic frameworks. In the absence of CH3CN the reaction gave [CuI(papo)] n (1) and [Cu3I3(papo)] n (2), whereas in the presence of CH3CN 2 and [Cu8I4(dmtrz)4] n (3; dmtrz = 3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazolate, from in situ ligand formation) were obtained. In the same pot in the presence of CH3CN, a red and mononuclear Cu(II) complex, [Cu(dmtap)2]I2 (4, dmtap = 2,4-dimethyl-1,3,5-triazapentadiene), was also isolated which supports the in situ synthesis of dmtrz by a non-ammonia pathway. The single and double stair-step structures of 1 and 2 are composed of single and double CuI-chains, respectively, and these chains are further linked through bridging papo ligands to form sheet structures. Although classical hydrogen bonding interactions in 1 is found absent, these interactions between amide−iodide in 2 were observed and found to increase its structural complexity. 3 contains a distorted Cu(I)-I cubane tetramer, four μ3-bridging dmtrz ligands, and eight 2-coordinate Cu(I) ions in one asymmetric unit. Each Cu(I) or I links three neighboring I or Cu(I) to form such a distorted cubane tetramer, and this coordination mode makes 3 potentially a three-dimensional porous network. The solid-state luminescence of 2 and 3 has also been investigated at room temperature and at 77 K.

elements.content: [Cu8I4(dmtrz)4] n being a novel three-dimensional porous network with a channel size of ca. 13 Å contains a distorted Cu4I4 cubane tetramer, four μ3-bridging dmtrz ligands, and eight 2-coordinate Cu(I) ions in one asymmetric unit, in which dmtrz was obtained by the in situ ligand formation in the presence of CH3CN in the reaction media.

elements.content: Copper(I) iodides are fascinating building blocks in the self-assembly process. Reactions involving copper(I) iodides and multidentate ligands may lead to the formation of various coordination networks containing structural motifs such as rhomboid dimers, cubane tetramers, zigzag polymers, and stair step polymers, which also possess rich luminescence. Moreover, the structural motifs often depend on the synthetic conditions employed, and thus copper(I) iodide clusters show structural versatilities with resulting luminescent properties closely correlated with their structural characteristics, for example, from Cu(I)···Cu(I) interactions. To date, a challenge encountered in crystal engineering is the predictability of the polymeric networks and dimensionalities, since they have been found to be dependent on the coordinating abilities of the metal ions, metal/ligand ratios, flexibility of the ligand backbones, and the presence of counterions and solvates in the crystal lattices. In this regard, copper(I) iodides are particularly of interest and significance to give a variety of self-assembled products, which addresses the growing interest in crystal engineering for the construction of a wide range of infinite solid-state coordination architectures and the search for new materials containing functionalities for chemical sieving, sensing, catalysis, and gas sorption.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Copper(I) iodides are fascinating building blocks in the self-assembly process. Reactions involving copper(I) iodides and multidentate ligands may lead to the formation of various coordination networks containing structural motifs such as rhomboid dimers, cubane tetramers, zigzag polymers, and stair step polymers, which also possess rich luminescence. Moreover, the structural motifs often depend on the synthetic conditions employed, and thus copper(I) iodide clusters show structural versatilities with resulting luminescent properties closely correlated with their structural characteristics, for example, from Cu(I)⋅⋅⋅Cu(I) interactions. To date, a challenge encountered in crystal engineering is the predictability of the polymeric networks and dimensionalities, since they have been found to be dependent on the coordinating abilities of the metal ions, metal/ligand ratios, flexibility of the ligand backbones, and the presence of counterions and solvates in the crystal lattices. In this regard, copper(I) iodides are particularly of interest and significance to give a variety of self-assembled products, which addresses the growing interest in crystal engineering for the construction of a wide range of infinite solid-state coordination architectures and the search for new materials containing functionalities for chemical sieving, sensing, catalysis, and gas sorption.

elements.content: In continuing our previous efforts to investigate the self-assembly of metal−organic frameworks based on pyridyl amides, the dipyridyl-amide ligand, papo, has attracted our attention for its hydrogen-bonding ability, which is very important for molecular recognition between receptors and substrates as well as the construction of complicated supramolecular frameworks. In addition, the incorporation of transition metal ions in the hydrogen-bonded networks is also important because the magnetic and optical characteristics of these ions become part of a broader strategy for crystal engineering of nonlinear optical, conducting, ferromagnetic, and luminescent materials. However, related reports based on the use of papo in self-assembly is still limited, and this prompted us to initiate this study. We report herein studies on the self-assembly reaction of copper(I)-iodides and papo, where a novel three-dimensional (3-D) coordination network built from copper(I)-iodides and 3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazolate, a ligand formed in situ from the solvent, was serendipitously isolated and characterized by X-ray diffraction. Its thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and solid-state luminescence were also investigated.

In addition, the incorporation of transition metal ions in the hydrogen-bonded networks is also important because the magnetic and optical characteristics of these ions become part of a broader strategy for crystal engineering of nonlinear optical, conducting, ferromagnetic, and luminescent materials. However, related reports based on the use of papo in self-assembly is still limited, and this prompted us to initiate this study. We report herein studies on the self-assembly reaction of copper(I)-iodides and papo, where a novel three-dimensional (3-D) coordination network built from copper(I)-iodides and 3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazolate, a ligand formed in situ from the solvent, was serendipitously isolated and characterized by X-ray diffraction. Its thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and solid-state luminescence were also investigated.

elements.content: All solvents for syntheses (analytical grade) were used without further purification, and CuI was obtained commercially. The papo ligand was prepared following a literature method. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded in the form of KBr pellets on a Perkin-Elmer PC 16 FTIR spectrometer, and steady-state emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer. TGA was performed under N2 flow at a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a Shimadzu TGA-50 system. The powder X-ray diffraction data were recorded on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer. The sorption isotherms for hydrogen and nitrogen at 77 K were recorded on a BELSORP-max volumetric-adsorption instrument from BEL Japan, Inc. The solid samples for elemental analysis (EA) were treated under vacuum overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Information

All solvents for syntheses (analytical grade) were used without further purification, and CuI was obtained commercially. The papo ligand was prepared following a literature method. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded in the form of KBr pellets on a Perkin-Elmer PC 16 FTIR spectrometer, and steady-state emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer. TGA was performed under N2 flow at a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a Shimadzu TGA-50 system. The powder X-ray diffraction data were recorded on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer. The sorption isotherms for hydrogen and nitrogen at 77 K were recorded on a BELSORP-max volumetric-adsorption instrument from BEL Japan, Inc. The solid samples for elemental analysis (EA) were treated under vacuum overnight.

elements.content: CuI (19 mg, 0.1 mmol) dissolved in a saturated methanolic solution of KI (3 mL) was carefully layered onto a 3 mL CH3OH/CHCl3 (1:1) solution of papo (41 mg, 0.1 mmol). Yellow crystals of 1 and 2 were obtained in 1 week with a total yield of 87% (based on CuI). Because of the similar colors and shapes for 1 and 2, the separation of the two complexes was not possible.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [CuI(papo)] n  (1) and [Cu3I3(papo)] n  (2)

CuI (19 mg, 0.1 mmol) dissolved in a saturated methanolic solution of KI (3 mL) was carefully layered onto a 3 mL CH3OH/CHCl3 (1:1) solution of papo (41 mg, 0.1 mmol). Yellow crystals of 1 and 2 were obtained in 1 week with a total yield of 87% (based on CuI). Because of the similar colors and shapes for 1 and 2, the separation of the two complexes was not possible.

elements.content: CuI (19 mg, 0.1 mmol) dissolved in a saturated methanolic solution of KI (3 mL) was carefully layered onto a 3 mL CH3CN/CHCl3 (1:1) solution of papo (41 mg, 0.1 mmol). Yellow, brown, and red crystals of 2, 3, and 4, respectively, were obtained in 1 week with a total yield of 81% (based on CuI). They can be easily separated by their colors and/or shapes with 25%, 48%, and 8% yields for 2, 3, and 4, respectively. FT-IR (KBr) for 2: νNH = 3358 cm−1, νCO = 1667 cm−1, νCC = 1598, 1498 cm−1. Synthesis of [Cu3I3(papo)] n  (2), [Cu8I4(dmtrz)4] n  (3), and [Cu(dmtap)2]I2 (4)

CuI (19 mg, 0.1 mmol) dissolved in a saturated methanolic solution of KI (3 mL) was carefully layered onto a 3 mL CH3CN/CHCl3 (1:1) solution of papo (41 mg, 0.1 mmol). Yellow, brown, and red crystals of 2, 3, and 4, respectively, were obtained in 1 week with a total yield of 81% (based on CuI). They can be easily separated by their colors and/or shapes with 25%, 48%, and 8% yields for 2, 3, and 4, respectively. FT-IR (KBr) for 2: νNH = 3358 cm-1, νCO = 1667 cm-1, νCC = 1598, 1498 cm-1. Anal. Calcd (%) for C24H18Cu3I3N4O3: C, 29.36; H, 1.85; N, 5.71. Found (%): C, 29.54; H, 1.96; N, 6.02. FT-IR (KBr) for 3: νCN/CC = 1627 and 1496 cm-1. Anal. Calcd (%) for C16H24Cu8I4N12: C, 13.72; H, 1.73; N, 12.00. Found (%): C, 13.45; H, 1.52; N, 12.28. FT-IR (KBr) for 4: νNH = 3220 cm-1, νCN = 1670 and 1551 cm-1. Anal. Calcd (%) for C8H18CuI2N6: C, 18.63; H, 3.52; N, 16.30. Found (%): C, 18.55; H, 3.39; N, 16.62.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of 1, 2, 3, and 4 were each mounted on a glass capillary, and data collection was carried out on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with Mo radiation (0.71073 Å) at 295 K. Low-temperature diffraction data for 3 were also collected at 150 K for comparison. A preliminary orientation matrix and unit cell parameters were determined from 3 runs of 15 frames each, each frame corresponding to 0.3° scan in 20 s, followed by spot integration and least-squares refinement. Data were collected using an ω scan of 0.3° per frame for 20 s until a complete hemisphere had been covered. Cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined with SAINT on all observed reflections. Data reduction was performed with the SAINT software and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Absorption corrections were applied with the program SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods with the SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 with SHELXL-97 All non-hydrogen atomic positions were located in difference Fourier maps and refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were constrained to the ideal geometry using an appropriate riding model. Detailed data collection and refinement of 1, 2, 3, and 4 are summarized in Table , and their selected bond distances and angles are summarized in Table .

X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals of 1, 2, 3, and 4 were each mounted on a glass capillary, and data collection was carried out on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with Mo radiation (0.71073 Å) at 295 K. Low-temperature diffraction data for 3 were also collected at 150 K for comparison. A preliminary orientation matrix and unit cell parameters were determined from 3 runs of 15 frames each, each frame corresponding to 0.3° scan in 20 s, followed by spot integration and least-squares refinement. Data were collected using an ω scan of 0.3° per frame for 20 s until a complete hemisphere had been covered. Cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined with SAINT on all observed reflections. Data reduction was performed with the SAINT software and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Absorption corrections were applied with the program SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods with the SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 with SHELXL-97 All non-hydrogen atomic positions were located in difference Fourier maps and refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were constrained to the ideal geometry using an appropriate riding model. Detailed data collection and refinement of 1, 2, 3, and 4 are summarized in Table , and their selected bond distances and angles are summarized in Table .

Recently, in situ metal/ligand reactions carried out at elevated temperatures (e.g., under solvothermal conditions) or at room temperature (e.g., by a layer method) have been recognized as a powerful technique for the construction of new metal−organic frameworks that exhibit intriguing structural diversity and promising physical/chemical properties for potential applications. In addition, this synthetic method is a very important research field in both coordination chemistry and organic chemistry, which has been studied for the discovery of new organic reactions, elucidation of reaction mechanisms, as well as generation of new ligands for novel coordination compounds. Thus, it is interesting to initiate a self-assembly reaction taking advantage of in situ ligand formation with aforementioned copper(I) iodides, to search for new metal−organic networks, although the in situ reaction to form ligands is sometimes serendipitous.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Recently, in situ metal/ligand reactions carried out at elevated temperatures (e.g., under solvothermal conditions) or at room temperature (e.g., by a layer method) have been recognized as a powerful technique for the construction of new metal-organic frameworks that exhibit intriguing structural diversity and promising physical/chemical properties for potential applications. In addition, this synthetic method is a very important research field in both coordination chemistry and organic chemistry, which has been studied for the discovery of new organic reactions, elucidation of reaction mechanisms, as well as generation of new ligands for novel coordination compounds. Thus, it is interesting to initiate a self-assembly reaction taking advantage of in situ ligand formation with aforementioned copper(I) iodides, to search for new metal-organic networks, although the in situ reaction to form ligands is sometimes serendipitous.

elements.content: The reactions for the formation of complexes 1−4 are shown in Scheme . All complexes were synthesized and isolated as air-stable solids by a layer method. Since 1 and 2 are both yellow, they were isolated only as a mixture. On the other hand, there is no difficulty to separate 2, 3, and 4 due to their different colors (2: yellow; 3: brown; 4: red). The molecular structures were determined by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction, confirming the formation of two-dimensional (2-D) and 3-D coordination networks based on the papo ligand and the in situ generated dmtrz ligand, respectively, as well as a mononuclear Cu(II) complex, 4, with a particularly rare red color. The Cu(II) ions in 4 are assumed to originate from the oxidation of the starting Cu(I) metal salts in the reaction. Given some uncharacterized powder products in each experiment, we had difficulty to confirm that 1 did not exist in the reaction system in the presence of CH3CN, although we have not isolated 1 as the single-crystalline product yet.

The Cu(II) ions in 4 are assumed to originate from the oxidation of the starting Cu(I) metal salts in the reaction. Given some uncharacterized powder products in each experiment, we had difficulty to confirm that 1 did not exist in the reaction system in the presence of CH3CN, although we have not isolated 1 as the single-crystalline product yet.

The 2-D ORTEP diagram of 1 is shown in Figure , which crystallized in the space group of C 2. The refined absolute Flack parameter is 0.08(6), indicating that 1 is an acentric compound. The CuI ion adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry, constructed from one nitrogen atom of the pyridyl ring in papo and three bridging-iodides. Its single stair-step structure is composed of Cu2I2 dimer units (Cu(I)···Cu(I) = 3.0162(15) Å; Cu(I)···I = 2.602(2), 2.6604(12) Å), which are connected into chains through additional Cu(I)···Cu(I) and Cu(I)···I bridging interactions (Cu(I)···Cu(I) = 3.0162(15) Å; Cu(I)···I = 2.758(2) Å). Description of Crystal Structures

The 2-D ORTEP diagram of 1 is shown in Figure , which crystallized in the space group of C 2. The refined absolute Flack parameter is 0.08(6), indicating that 1 is an acentric compound. The CuI ion adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry, constructed from one nitrogen atom of the pyridyl ring in papo and three bridging-iodides. Its single stair-step structure is composed of Cu2I2 dimer units (Cu(I)⋅⋅⋅Cu(I) = 3.0162(15) Å; Cu(I)⋅⋅⋅I = 2.602(2), 2.6604(12) Å), which are connected into chains through additional Cu(I)⋅⋅⋅Cu(I) and Cu(I)⋅⋅⋅I bridging interactions (Cu(I)⋅⋅⋅Cu(I) = 3.0162(15) Å; Cu(I)⋅⋅⋅I = 2.758(2) Å). In addition, these Cu(I)-I chains are further linked through bridging papo ligands to form a sheet structure. It is noted that there is no amide-amide hydrogen bonding to occur between the sheet structures in 1, and only a long amide-iodide contact (N(2)⋅⋅⋅I(1), 3.916(1) Å; the sum of the van der Waals radii for N and I atoms are 3.53 Å) can be observed.

elements.content: Figure shows the 2-D ORTEP diagram of 2, which crystallized in the space group of P21/c. The CuI ion also adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry, constructed from one nitrogen atom of the pyridyl ring in papo and three bridging-iodides. Unlike that of 1, the structure of 2 employs the Cu3I3 unit instead of the Cu2I2 unit to form Cu(I)-I chains, which are further extended into a sheet structure through bridging papo ligands (Cu(I)···Cu(I) = 2.804(2)−3.028(2) Å; Cu(I)···I = 2.5841(18)−2.6998(19) Å). Thus, two remarkably different structures of the single stair-step in 1, and the double stair-step in 2 can be obtained in a one-pot reaction. Moreover, the Cu(I)···Cu(I) distances of 3.0162(15) and 2.804(2)−3.028(2) Å for 1 and 2, respectively, are only slightly longer than the sum of van der Waals radii of Cu (2.80 Å), indicating that weak cuprophilic interactions are possible. However, the Cu(I)···I distances of 2.602(2)−2.6604(12) and 2.758(2) Å for 1 and 2, respectively, are significantly shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii (3.38 Å for Cu(I)···I), and are suggestive of Cu(I)···I interactions. The C−O−C angles of 119.6(10) and 120.6(9)° in papo for both 1 and 2, respectively, are quite similar, and thus makes the reason and origin of the difference in their structural motifs inconclusive. To our knowledge, the double stair-step structure of 2 represents a rare example of the Cu(I)-I system. Similar to that of 1, the amide−amide hydrogen bonding in 2 was also found absent, and only a short amide−iodide contact (N(2)···I(1), 3.7492(1) Å) can be observed. The above contact should be considered as a weak interaction leading the layers to dimers of layers and increasing the structural complexity in 2. The absence of the amide−amide interactions in both 1 and 2 are most likely due to structural crowding for Cu(I)-I chains in the crystal lattices.

elements.content: 3 crystallized in the space group of I41/a, and its molecular structure with 30% probability ellipsoids and packing diagram are shown in Figure , panels a and b, respectively. Unlike 1 and 2 with papo as bridging ligands in the structural backbone, 3 contains a distorted Cu(I)-I cubane tetramer and μ3-bridging dmtrz-Cu(I) units, where dmtrz was obtained by in situ formation in the presence of CH3CN. A repeating unit of a distorted Cu(I)-I cubane (the occupancy for Cu(I) is 1.0), four μ3-bridging dmtrz ligands, and eight 2-coordinate Cu(I) ions (the occupancy for Cu(I) is 0.5) can be recognized in the extended structure. Similar to those of other reported Cu4I4 tetramer units, each Cu(I) or I links three neighboring I or Cu(I) to form such a distorted cubane tetramer, and this coordination mode makes 3 potentially a 3-D porous network with a channel size of ca. 13 Å (void percentage: 53.2% calculated by the Platon Graphics). The Cu(I)···Cu(I) and Cu(I)···I distances in the cubane are within 2.6301(18)−2.8364(16) and 2.5887(11)−2.8298(12) Å, respectively, which are slightly shorter than those of 1 and 2, and comparable to those of structurally characterized Cu4I4L4 (L = nitrogen-containing ligand) complexes. In addition, there are close Cu(I)···Cu(I) and Cu(I)···I contacts within 3.31−3.61 and 3.26−3.33 Å, respectively, in the structural backbones outside the cubane tetramers. The Cu(I)···Cu(I) distances are significantly longer than the sum of van der Waals radii, and any cuprophilic interaction can be excluded. However, the Cu(I)···I distances are slightly shorter than their sum of van der Waals radii, indicative of weak Cu(I)···I interactions. For comparison, the X-ray diffraction data of 3 were also collected at 150 K. The low-temperature X-ray data of 3 show that for the cubane tetramer, the Cu(I)···I (2.5881(11)−2.8336(11) Å) distances are comparable to those measured at room temperature, whereas the Cu(I)···Cu(I) distances (Cu(I)···Cu(I) = 2.6004(19)−2.7882(16) Å) are significantly shorter. This decrease in Cu(I)···Cu(I) distances is mostly ascribed to an enhancement of cuprophilic interactions upon cooling the solid samples. Additionally, when each cubane unit and dmtrz ligand are respectively treated as four- (tetrahedral - the cyanic circle) and three-connecting nodes (trigonal - the red circle) as shown in Figure c, the topology of 3 can be (62,10)4(64,102) - a jph (racemic) net. The jph net has vertex symbols 6·6·102 and 6·6·6·6·122·122, and genus 7. An interesting variation of the jph net with tetrahedral nodes instead of square planar ones linking the 4-fold helices is also found in the diaminotriazine substituted pentaerythrityltetraphenylether.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the molecular structure of 4 is similar to the neutral [Cu(4-pytap)2] complex (4-Hpytap = 2,4-di(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazapentadiene), where 4-pytap is an anionic ligand. The Cu(II) ion is chelated by two bidentate dmtap ligands to furnish a square-planar coordination environment. The Cu−N bond lengths are 1.943(3) Å, which are similar to those of [Cu(4-pytap)2] (1.941(1) and 1.954(1) Å). In addition, there are two counteranions (I−) hydrogen-bonded to each H−N of the amine unit and two H−N of the coordinated imine units (N(1)···I(1), 3.666(1) Å; N(2)···I(1), 3.598(8) Å; N(3)···I(1), 3.697(1) Å) leading to the formation of complicated hydrogen-bonded frameworks. The Cu(II)···Cu(II) distance is 4.15 Å along the c axis, which is too long to be considered as a weak interaction.

elements.content: Several possible mechanisms regarding the in situ formation of triazoles have been discussed, in which diazabutadiene-1,4-diamine (I), 1,3,5-triazapentadiene (II) (where this pathway can be performed in the presence or absence of ammonia), and the dicopper site (III) are three possible intermediates. Amidine, from the reaction of nitrile and ammonia, is known to add to another nitrile to give 1,3,5-triazapentadiene, which may further undergo a two-electron oxidative cyclization to form the triazole. Alternatively, 1,3,5-triazapentadiene can also be derived from the decomposition of 1,3,5-triazine, which can be generated from the trimerization of nitrile molecules. The mechanism in the presence of ammonia has been used to rationalize the formation of a mixed-valence triazolate complex, {[CuII 3CuI 6(4-pytap)6(4-pytz)2]·4BF4·8H2O} (4-Hpytz = 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole), in Chen’s work, since 1,3,5-triazapentadiene was also isolated along with [Cu(4-pytap)2] and {[CuII 3CuI 6(4-pytap)6(4-pytz)2]·4BF4·8H2O}. On the other hand, the mechanism in the absence of ammonia did not explain Chen’s results because ammonia had been used in his experiments. When ammonia is added to our reaction, 3 was isolated only in a very low yield (<5%). Moreover, the dmtap ligand in 4 was also isolated as an evidence for the formation of the triazolate ligand in 3 in our study. Hence, under our reaction conditions, Scheme can be used adequately to explain the in situ formation of dmtrz.

Both 2 and 3 are emissive at room temperature and at 77 K, and their spectra are shown in Figure , panels a and b, respectively. Upon photoexcitation at 300−350 nm at room temperature, solid samples of 2 show a low-energy emission with a maximum at 555 nm and also a tailing to 660 nm. Given that there is a significant red shift from papo to 2, where papo poorly emits at room temperature and shows an emission maximum at 440 nm at 77 K, this low-energy emission at 555 nm is most likely to originate from an iodo-to-papo charge-transfer (ligand-to-ligand charge-transfer, LLCT) transition. The above assignment is based on the strong σ-donating strength of iodide and low-energy π* orbital of papo, and on our previous spectral assignments on [ZnI2(L)]2 (L = N,N′-bis-4-methylpyridyl oxalamide) and [CuI(L1)] n (L1 = N,N′,N′′-tris(3-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxamide), and other reports.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Emission Spectra

Both 2 and 3 are emissive at room temperature and at 77 K, and their spectra are shown in Figure , panels a and b, respectively. Upon photoexcitation at 300-350 nm at room temperature, solid samples of 2 show a low-energy emission with a maximum at 555 nm and also a tailing to 660 nm. Given that there is a significant red shift from papo to 2, where papo poorly emits at room temperature and shows an emission maximum at 440 nm at 77 K, this low-energy emission at 555 nm is most likely to originate from an iodo-to-papo charge-transfer (ligand-to-ligand charge-transfer, LLCT) transition. The above assignment is based on the strong σ-donating strength of iodide and low-energy π* orbital of papo, and on our previous spectral assignments on [ZnI2(L)]2 (L = N,N'-bis-4-methylpyridyl oxalamide) and [CuI(L1)] n  (L1 = N,N',N''-tris(3-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxamide), and other reports.

elements.content: Upon cooling to 77 K, the emission at 555 nm is red-shifted to 566 nm and a new and weak emission at 640 nm appears, and indeed this red shift is coincident with the recent observations of [CuX(2,3-dimethylpyrazine)] (X = Cl, Br, I) reported by Näther et al. and our previous example of [CuI(L′)] n , which were also given a similar LLCT assignment. However, the tailing to 660 nm at room temperature, and a new and weak emission at 640 nm at 77 K for 2 might be assigned as a consequence of a ‘‘cluster-centered’’ (CC) excited-state in combination with an LLCT transition. Upon photoexcitation at 300−350 nm, 3 shows a structured emission with maxima at 377, 395, and 415 nm and then a tailing to 620 nm at room temperature, and they are red-shifted to a similarly structured spectrum with maxima at 386, 410, and 438 nm and also a tailing to 630 nm at 77 K. It is noted that even in the presence of the Cu(I) cubane with weak cuprophilic interactions, there is no significant red-shift in emission energies upon cooling the solid samples of 3 to 77 K. With reference to the previous study, the emissions at 350−600 nm with vibronic progressions (1200−1500 cm−1) are most likely ascribed to an intraligand (IL) transition. However, the presence of CC and LLCT excited states underneath the emission at 500−600 nm is still possible.

elements.content: The PXRD recorded at room temperature for solid samples of 2 and 3 are highly similar to their simulated ones (based on the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data), indicating that they are isolated as pure samples. To examine the thermal stability of 3, its TGA analysis was also recorded (). The weight loss of 6.4% (5H2O: 6.0%) for 3 is obtained upon heating the solid samples to 65 °C. Since each molecular formula contains only four water molecules in crystal lattices, the weight loss of an additional water is thus tentatively ascribed to the water adsorption when the samples were kept in air. Thus, the four water molecules can be easily removed from the lattices at 65 °C. It is likely that these water molecules could also be removed under a vacuum overnight for elemental analysis, which would explain why there is a loss of a water molecule in the EA of 3. However, the weight loss starts to increase slightly from 165 to 290 °C, and finally it can be thoroughly burned into CuO (a residue weight percentage of 42.6% compared with the calculated 41.2%) when the samples are heated up to 500−550 °C. To examine the porosity of 3, its hydrogen sorption was carried out. Unfortunately, the hydrogen sorption capacity can only be up to 0.63 wt % at 1 atm (77 K) and the surface area is calculated to be 420 m2/g (). This low hydrogen sorption may be ascribed to the poor affinity of polar triazolate groups toward nonpolar hydrogen. Indeed, this result is also consistent with the proposition by Kitagawa et al. that the methanol molecule is bound to the amide groups of {[Cd(L2)2(NO3)2]} n (L2 = N,N′,N′′-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxamide) in a 1:1 ratio. This is because the amide groups on the channel surfaces function effectively and give rise to an attractive interaction with the methanol molecules via hydrogen bonding.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis and Hydrogen Sorption Study

The PXRD recorded at room temperature for solid samples of 2 and 3 are highly similar to their simulated ones (based on the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data), indicating that they are isolated as pure samples. To examine the thermal stability of 3, its TGA analysis was also recorded (). The weight loss of 6.4% (5H2O: 6.0%) for 3 is obtained upon heating the solid samples to 65 °C. Since each molecular formula contains only four water molecules in crystal lattices, the weight loss of an additional water is thus tentatively ascribed to the water adsorption when the samples were kept in air. Thus, the four water molecules can be easily removed from the lattices at 65 °C. It is likely that these water molecules could also be removed under a vacuum overnight for elemental analysis, which would explain why there is a loss of a water molecule in the EA of 3. However, the weight loss starts to increase slightly from 165 to 290 °C, and finally it can be thoroughly burned into CuO (a residue weight percentage of 42.6% compared with the calculated 41.2%) when the samples are heated up to 500-550 °C. To examine the porosity of 3, its hydrogen sorption was carried out. Unfortunately, the hydrogen sorption capacity can only be up to 0.63 wt % at 1 atm (77 K) and the surface area is calculated to be 420 m2/g (). This low hydrogen sorption may be ascribed to the poor affinity of polar triazolate groups toward nonpolar hydrogen. Indeed, this result is also consistent with the proposition by Kitagawa et al. that the methanol molecule is bound to the amide groups of {[Cd(L2)2(NO3)2]} n  (L2 = N,N',N''-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxamide) in a 1:1 ratio. This is because the amide groups on the channel surfaces function effectively and give rise to an attractive interaction with the methanol molecules via hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: In this study, Cu(I)-I and the papo ligand reacted to give new metal−organic networks, and the reaction outcome indeed depends on the presence or absence of CH3CN in the reaction media. In the absence of CH3CN the reaction gave 1 and 2, whereas in the presence of CH3CN, complexes 2, 3, and 4 were obtained instead. The single and double stair-step structures of 1 and 2 are composed of single and double CuI-chains, respectively, and these chains are further linked through bridging papo ligands to form sheet structures. Unlike 1, classical hydrogen bonding interactions between amide−iodide in 2 were found to increase its structural complexity. Complex 3 contains a distorted Cu(I)-I cubane tetramer, four μ3-bridging dmtrz ligands, and eight 2-coordinate Cu(I) ions in one asymmetric unit, where dmtrz was formed by in situ synthesis from CH3CN. Each Cu(I) or I links three neighboring I or Cu(I) to form such a distorted cubane tetramer, and this coordination mode makes 3 potentially a 3-D porous network. Most significantly, the isolation of 4 supports that the in situ ligand synthesis of the triazole ligand can be accomplished by a non-ammonia pathway. This work not only highlights a new in situ ligand formation mechanism for the triazole ligand, but also provides a supramolecular synthesis toward the formation of potentially porous frameworks by the in situ polydentate ligand and the Cu(I)-I cubane acting as useful building blocks. Thus, an interesting family of functional metal−organic frameworks generated by taking the above strategy may be anticipated.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this study, Cu(I)-I and the papo ligand reacted to give new metal-organic networks, and the reaction outcome indeed depends on the presence or absence of CH3CN in the reaction media. In the absence of CH3CN the reaction gave 1 and 2, whereas in the presence of CH3CN, complexes 2, 3, and 4 were obtained instead. The single and double stair-step structures of 1 and 2 are composed of single and double CuI-chains, respectively, and these chains are further linked through bridging papo ligands to form sheet structures. Unlike 1, classical hydrogen bonding interactions between amide-iodide in 2 were found to increase its structural complexity. Complex 3 contains a distorted Cu(I)-I cubane tetramer, four μ3-bridging dmtrz ligands, and eight 2-coordinate Cu(I) ions in one asymmetric unit, where dmtrz was formed by in situ synthesis from CH3CN. Each Cu(I) or I links three neighboring I or Cu(I) to form such a distorted cubane tetramer, and this coordination mode makes 3 potentially a 3-D porous network. Most significantly, the isolation of 4 supports that the in situ ligand synthesis of the triazole ligand can be accomplished by a non-ammonia pathway. This work not only highlights a new in situ ligand formation mechanism for the triazole ligand, but also provides a supramolecular synthesis toward the formation of potentially porous frameworks by the in situ polydentate ligand and the Cu(I)-I cubane acting as useful building blocks. Thus, an interesting family of functional metal-organic frameworks generated by taking the above strategy may be anticipated.

cln_elements.content:
Both 2 and 3 are emissive at room temperature and at 77 K, and their spectra are shown in Figure , panels a and b, respectively. Upon photoexcitation at 300−350 nm at room temperature, solid samples of 2 show a low-energy emission with a maximum at 555 nm and also a tailing to 660 nm. Given that there is a significant red shift from papo to 2, where papo poorly emits at room temperature and shows an emission maximum at 440 nm at 77 K, this low-energy emission at 555 nm is most likely to originate from an iodo-to-papo charge-transfer (ligand-to-ligand charge-transfer, LLCT) transition. The above assignment is based on the strong σ-donating strength of iodide and low-energy π* orbital of papo, and on our previous spectral assignments on [ZnI2(L)]2 (L = N,N′-bis-4-methylpyridyl oxalamide) and [CuI(L1)] n (L1 = N,N′,N′′-tris(3-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxamide), and other reports.

Thermogravimetric Analysis and Hydrogen Sorption Study

The PXRD recorded at room temperature for solid samples of 2 and 3 are highly similar to their simulated ones (based on the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data), indicating that they are isolated as pure samples. To examine the thermal stability of 3, its TGA analysis was also recorded (). The weight loss of 6.4% (5H2O: 6.0%) for 3 is obtained upon heating the solid samples to 65 °C. Since each molecular formula contains only four water molecules in crystal lattices, the weight loss of an additional water is thus tentatively ascribed to the water adsorption when the samples were kept in air. Thus, the four water molecules can be easily removed from the lattices at 65 °C. It is likely that these water molecules could also be removed under a vacuum overnight for elemental analysis, which would explain why there is a loss of a water molecule in the EA of 3. However, the weight loss starts to increase slightly from 165 to 290 °C, and finally it can be thoroughly burned into CuO (a residue weight percentage of 42.6% compared with the calculated 41.2%) when the samples are heated up to 500−550 °C. To examine the porosity of 3, its hydrogen sorption was carried out. Unfortunately, the hydrogen sorption capacity can only be up to 0.63 wt % at 1 atm (77 K) and the surface area is calculated to be 420 m2/g (). This low hydrogen sorption may be ascribed to the poor affinity of polar triazolate groups toward nonpolar hydrogen. Indeed, this result is also consistent with the proposition by Kitagawa et al. that the methanol molecule is bound to the amide groups of {[Cd(L2)2(NO3)2]} n (L2 = N,N′,N′′-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxamide) in a 1:1 ratio. This is because the amide groups on the channel surfaces function effectively and give rise to an attractive interaction with the methanol molecules via hydrogen bonding.
